COAL MINING.The increase in unemployment which normally takes place in this industry during the summer months was accentuated in the last quarter by other difficulties. Under-employment was very prevalent in most districts, but some improvement can be looked for in the near future with an increasing home demand for coal.IRON AND STEEL.The improvement in these industries was not maintained during the last quarter. Production began to show signs of slackening off towards the end of March, as the arrears of work accumulated during the dispute period were completed and a slight increase in unemployment occurred towards the end of the quarter. The tin-plate industry suffered a severe set-back, the percentage of unemployment rising from 5*5 to 22'5 per cent, during the period.SHIPBUILDING AND SHIP-REPAIRING.A considerable amount of new tonnage was commenced during the last quarter, and the position of this industry showed an appreciable improvement during April and May. This recovery was not, however, maintained during June, and at the end of that month the percentage of unemployment was still 22*9 per cent. [ENGINEERING.On the whole the engineering position improved throughout the quarter. Employment in general engineering was fairly good, while a substantial improve-ment took place in marine engineering and in constructional engineering. The electrical section continued to be active, and in motor engineering employment was also good, although signs of seasonal slackening were apparent towards the end of the quarter.TEXTILES.Cotton. Comparatively little change occurred in the employment position of the cotton industry. In-the Egyptian spinning section employment remained good, but a considerable amount of short time was worked in the American section. Prospects are still uncertain."Woollen and Worsted. Some improvement took place in these industries in the beginning of the quarter, but a decline took place, particularly in the heavy woollen section, in June.Other Textiles. With the exception of jute and carpets, a slight improvement has been shown in all other branches of the textile trade.BUILDING. BRICK AND TILE MANUFACTURE.The activity which is normally experienced in this industry during the second quarter of the year was more pronounced than usual during the period under review. In June there was some slackness in the deoorating branch, ohiefly owing to inclement weather, but the improvement in the brick and tile industry was well maintained. clothing trades.Following the termination of the normal seasonal activity in these trades, employment showed a falling off in June. Unemployment at the end of the month was, however, lower than at the end of last quarter.pottery.The employment position in this industry continued to remain unsatisfactory, unemployment increasing in April and June.transport, dock labour and shipping services.A general improvement took place in all sections, and in particular at the London Docks. iii. work instituted for relief of unemployment.numbers employed.[see note on page 1 of november 1924 report (op. 541 (24)).]the table which follows has been prepared to show, so far as information is available, the number of men employed on works instituted, with financial assistance from the exchequer or the road fund, for the relief of unemployment.Scope of liable. the schemes included are those undertaken by local and other authorities and public companies with a financial contribution from the state with the object of relieving unemployment; (Dominions Office,)Under the Empire Settlement Act, 1922 (an Act to make better provision for furthering British, settlement in His Majesty's Oversea Dominions), various schemes have been.agreed with Dominion Authorities. This Act, as its title implies, is not one of the Government measures designed to deal with unemployment, and should not be so regarded. Neither is the cost included of certain training of ex-Service men carried out in Ireland at a cost to the Imperial Exchequer of approximately 255,425.[16478] Unemployment Insurance.(Estimates, Class V, Vote 7.)The National Insurance Act of 1911 provided Insurance against unemployment in certain selected industries. It was followed by the Act of 1916, which increased the numbers of persons insured, and, in 1920, by an Act of general scope which applied compulsory Insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons. Subsequent amending Acts modified the conditions of receipt of benefit, increased contributions, provided benefit in respect of dependants, and authorised the Treasury to make advances out of the Consolidated Fund up to a limit of 30,000,000.By the Unemployment Insurance (No. 2) Act, 1924, the rates of benefit were raised (from 15s.) to 18s. a week for men, and (from 12s.) to 15s. a week for women, with 2s. (instead of Is.) a week for each young dependent child. Until the 30th June, 1926, since extended by the Act of 1926 to the 31st December, 1927, benefit in respect of contributions may be paid for 26 weeks in a benefit year, while benefit, irrespective of contributions, may be paid during unemployment subject to the satisfaction of special conditions. The Act also amends the disqualification for benefit in the case of persons affected by trade disputes, and it abolishes the right to a refund of contributions at the age of 60, subject to the payment of compensation for the loss of refund rights in certain cases.Statement of Income and Expenditure from Armistice to July 2, 1927. 301,532,000 29,424,0002,906,0001,765,000 739,000 - 336,366,000113,150,000 101,851,000 77,104,000 3,839,000 -- 295,944,0005,825,000 5,825,000 3,884,000- 15,534,00023,970,000918,000336,366,000* Note.-The old Fund at November 8th, 1920, had reached a total of 22,210,000.Estimate of Benefit payable from Armistice to March 31, 1928, 336,870,000.Expenditure -Benefit paidAppropriation for AdministrationSection 9 Unemployment Insurance Act (No. 2), 1924, and Section 25-Unemployment Insurance Act, 1920Miscellaneous Refunds, &c.....Interest (Net)Income Contributions Employers Employed ExchequerExchequer (for ex-Service Men)Balance of Old Fund at Armistice (excluding Interest accrued) * Employers Employed exchequer loans from Treasury (Net).... .... ....Miscellaneous Deposits in respect of future Contribu-tions, &c..... Juveniles.After the Armistice, Juvenile Unemployment Centres were opened in certain localities to deal with the problem of unemployed juveniles. After a period of closure centres were again established, and the cost, which was originally shared by the Board of Education and Local Authorities, was, from the 1st April, 1923, to the 31st March, 1924, partly met out of Relief of Unemployment Vote by grants up to 75 per cent, in respect of approved schemes, the Local Authority providing the remaining 25 per cent. From the 1st April, 1924, the Exchequer Grant was, as an emergency measure, for so long as unemployment amongst juveniles remains acute, raised to 100 per cent, of the approved out-of-pocket expenses of Local Education Authorities.From the 1st April, 1926, the Exchequer Grant was revised as follows : (1.) To Axithorities in whose areas the average rate of unemployment among insured juveniles exceeded 6 per cent, during the twelve months which ended on the 23rd November, 1925.A per capita grant fixed by the Minister for each Authority separately equal to the approved average weekly cost to the Authority of each Juvenile in average attendance, taking into account recurrent expenditure only, during the twelve months which ended on the 30th June, 30th September, or 31st December, 1925, whichever was the latest period for which consecutive claims had been received. If complete figures for one year ending on one of the above dates were not available, or if the Authority had not previously opened Centres, the per capita grant was fixed by the Minister on such information, including the Authority's proposals for 1926, as was available to him.(2.) To Atithorities in whose areas the average rate of unemployment among insured juveniles was not less than 3 per cent, and not more than 6 per cent, during the twelve months which ended on the 23rd November, 1925.Either (i) a per capita grant calculated as in (1) above, but equal to three-quarters only of the approved average weekly cost, or (ii) a grant of 75 per cent, of the approved out-of-pocket expenditure incurred by the Authority during the financial year 1926, as the Authority chose.schemes for training women and juveniles and young unemployed fit men.(Estimates, Class V, Vote 8.)(a.)
